ol.li: Understand which is the best method to use to compute an orthogonal projection in a given situation.
Recipes: an orthonormal set from an orthogonal set, Projection Formula, \cB-coordinates when \cB is an orthogonal set, GramSchmidt process.
Vocabulary words: orthogonal set, orthonormal set.

introduction.p: In this section, we give a formula for orthogonal projection that is considerably simpler than the one in , in that it does not require row reduction or matrix inversion. However, this formula, called the Projection Formula, only works in the presence of an orthogonal basis. We will also present the GramSchmidt process for turning an arbitrary basis into an orthogonal one.

subsection.title: Orthogonal Sets and the Projection Formula
subsection.p: Computations involving projections tend to be much easier in the presence of an orthogonal set of vectors.

statement.p: A set of nonzero vectors \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_m\} is called orthogonal if u_i\cdot u_j = 0 whenever i\neq j. It is orthonormal if it is orthogonal, and in addition u_i\cdot u_i = 1 for all i=1,2,\ldots,m.

subsection.p: In other words, a set of vectors is orthogonal if different vectors in the set are perpendicular to each other. An orthonormal set is an orthogonal set of unit vectors.

statement.p: Is this set orthogonal? Is it orthonormal? \cB = \left\{\vec{1 1 1},\;\vec{1 -2 1},\;\vec{1 0 -1}\right\}

subsection.p: We saw in the previous example that it is easy to produce an orthonormal set of vectors from an orthogonal one by replacing each vector with the unit vector in the same direction.

bluebox.title: Recipe: An orthonormal set from an orthogonal set

statement.p:
Let a,b be scalars, and let
u_1 = \vec{a b} \qquad u_2 = \vec{-b a}.
Is \cB = \{u_1,u_2\} orthogonal?

solution.p:
We only have to check that
\vec{a b}\cdot\vec{-b a} = -ab + ab = 0.
Therefore, \{u_1,u_2\} is orthogonal, unless a=b=0.

This set is not orthogonal because
\vec{1 1 1}\cdot\vec{1 -1 -1} = 1-1-1 = -1 \neq 0.
We will see how to produce an orthogonal set from \cB in this .

subsection.p: A nice property enjoyed by orthogonal sets is that they are automatically linearly independent.

statement.p: An orthogonal set is linearly independent. Therefore, it is a basis for its span.

proof.p:
Suppose that \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_m\} is orthogonal. We need to show that the equation
c_1u_1 + c_2u_2 + \cdots + c_mu_m = 0
has only the trivial solution c_1=c_2=\cdots=c_m=0. Taking the dot product of both sides of this equation with u_1 gives
\begin{split} 0 = u_1\cdot 0 \amp= u_1\cdot\bigl(c_1u_1 + c_2u_2 + \cdots + c_mu_m\bigr) \\ \amp= c_1(u_1\cdot u_1) + c_2(u_1\cdot u_2) + \cdots + c_m(u_1\cdot u_m) \\ \amp= c_1(u_1\cdot u_1) \end{split}
because u_1\cdot u_i = 0 for i > 1. Since u_1\neq 0 we have u_1\cdot u_1\neq 0, so c_1 = 0. Similarly, taking the dot product with u_i shows that each c_i = 0, as desired.

subsection.p: One advantage of working with orthogonal sets is that it gives a simple formula for the orthogonal projection of a vector.

statement.p:
Let W be a subspace of \R^n, and let \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_m\} be an orthogonal basis for W. Then for any vector x in \R^n, the orthogonal projection of x onto W is given by the formula
x_W = \frac{x\cdot u_1}{u_1\cdot u_1}\,u_1 + \frac{x\cdot u_2}{u_2\cdot u_2}\,u_2 + \cdots + \frac{x\cdot u_m}{u_m\cdot u_m}\,u_m.

proof.p:
Let
y = \frac{x\cdot u_1}{u_1\cdot u_1}\,u_1 + \frac{x\cdot u_2}{u_2\cdot u_2}\,u_2 + \cdots + \frac{x\cdot u_m}{u_m\cdot u_m}\,u_m.
This vector is contained in W because it is a linear combination of u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_m. Hence we just need to show that x - y is in W^\perp, i.e., that u_i\cdot (x-y) = 0 for each i=1,2,\ldots,m. For u_1, we have
\begin{split} u_1\cdot(x-y) \amp= u_1\cdot\left( x - \frac{x\cdot u_1}{u_1\cdot u_1}\,u_1 - \frac{x\cdot u_2}{u_2\cdot u_2}\,u_2 - \cdots - \frac{x\cdot u_m}{u_m\cdot u_m}\,u_m \right) \\ \amp= u_1\cdot x - \frac{x\cdot u_1}{u_1\cdot u_1}(u_1\cdot u_1) - 0 - \cdots - 0 \\ \amp= 0. \end{split}
A similar calculation shows that u_i\cdot(x-y) = 0 for each i, so x-y is in W^\perp, as desired.

subsection.p:
If \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_m\} is an orthonormal basis for W, then the denominators u_i\cdot u_i = 1 go away, so the projection formula becomes even simpler:
x_W = (x\cdot u_1)\,u_1 + (x\cdot u_2)\,u_2 + \cdots + (x\cdot u_m)\,u_m.

specialcase.p:
Suppose that L = \Span\{u\} is a line. The set \{u\} is an orthogonal basis for L, so the Projection Formula says that for any vector x, we have
x_L = \frac{x\cdot u}{u\cdot u}\,u,
as in this . See also this and this .

statement.p: Continuing with this and this , use the to compute the orthogonal projection of a vector onto the xy-plane in \R^3.

solution.p:
A basis for the xy-plane is given by the two standard coordinate vectors
e_1 = \vec{1 0 0} \qquad e_2 = \vec{0 1 0}.
The set \{e_1,e_2\} is orthogonal, so for any vector x = (x_1,x_2,x_3), we have
x_W = \frac{x\cdot e_1}{e_1\cdot e_1}\,e_1 + \frac{x\cdot e_2}{e_2\cdot e_2}\,e_2 = x_1e_1 + x_2e_2 = \vec{x_1 x_2 0}.

figure.caption: Orthogonal projection of a vector onto the xy-plane in \R^3. Note that x_W is the sum of the projections of x onto the e_1- and e_2-coordinate axes (shown in orange and brown, respectively).

statement.p:
Let
W = \Span\left\{\vec{1 0 -1},\;\vec{1 1 1}\right\} \qquad x = \vec{2 3 -2}.
Find x_W and x_{W^\perp}.

solution.p:
The vectors
u_1 = \vec{1 0 -1} \qquad u_2 = \vec{1 1 1}
are orthogonal, so we can use the Projection Formula:
x_W = \frac{x\cdot u_1}{u_1\cdot u_1}\,u_1 + \frac{x\cdot u_2}{u_2\cdot u_2}\,u_2 = \frac{4}{2}\vec{1 0 -1} + \frac{3}{3}\vec{1 1 1} = \vec{3 1 -1}.
Then we have
x_{W^\perp} = x - x_W = \vec{-1 2 -1}.

figure.caption: Orthogonal projection of a vector onto the plane W. Note that x_W is the sum of the projections of x onto the lines spanned by u_1 and u_2 (shown in orange and brown, respectively).

statement.p:
Let
W = \Span\left\{\vec{1 0 -1 0},\;\vec{0 1 0 -1},\;\vec{1 1 1 1}\right\} \qquad x = \vec{0 1 3 4}.
Compute x_W, and find the distance from x to W.

subsection.p:
Now let W be a subspace of \R^n with orthogonal basis \cB=\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\}, and let x be a vector in W. Then x = x_W, so by the , we have
x = x_W = \frac{x\cdot u_1}{u_1\cdot u_1}\,u_1 + \frac{x\cdot u_2}{u_2\cdot u_2}\,u_2 + \cdots + \frac{x\cdot u_m}{u_m\cdot u_m}\,u_m.
This gives us a way of expressing x as a linear combination of the basis vectors in \cB: we have computed the \cB-coordinates of x without row reducing!

idx.h: with respect to an orthogonal basis

subsection.p: As with orthogonal projections, if \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_m\} is an orthonormal basis of W, then the formula is even simpler: [x]_\cB = \bigl(x\cdot u_1,\; x\cdot u_2,\; \ldots,\; x\cdot u_m\bigr).

subsection.title: The GramSchmidt Process
subsection.p: We saw in the previous subsection that orthogonal projections and \cB-coordinates are much easier to compute in the presence of an orthogonal basis for a subspace. In this subsection, we give a method, called the GramSchmidt Process, for computing an orthogonal basis of a subspace.

proof.p: First we claim that each u_i is in W, and in fact that u_i is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_i\}. Clearly u_1 = v_1 is in \Span\{v_1\}. Then u_2 is a linear combination of u_1 and v_2, which are both in \Span\{v_1,v_2\}, so u_2 is in \Span\{v_1,v_2\} as well. Similarly, u_3 is a linear combination of u_1,\,u_2, and v_3, which are all in \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_3\}, so u_3 is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_3\}. Continuing in this way, we see that each u_i is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_i\}.

Now we claim that \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_m\} is an orthogonal set. Let 1\leq i \lt j \leq m. Then u_j = (v_j)_{\Span\{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_{j-1}\}^\perp}, so by definition u_j is orthogonal to every vector in \Span\{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_{j-1}\}. In particular, u_j is orthogonal to u_i.

We still have to prove that each u_i is nonzero. Clearly u_1=v_1\neq 0. Suppose that u_i=0. Then (v_i)_{\Span\{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_{i-1}\}^\perp}=0, which means that v_i is in \Span\{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_{i-1}\}. But each u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_{i-1} is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{i-1}\} by the first paragraph, so v_i is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{i-1}\}. This contradicts the increasing span criterion; therefore, u_i must be nonzero.

Since \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_m\} is an orthogonal set, it is linearly independent. Thus it is a set of m linearly independent vectors in W, so it is a basis for W by the . Similarly, for every i, we saw that the set \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_i\} is contained in the i-dimensional subspace \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_i\}, so \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_i\} is an orthogonal basis for \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_i\}.

statement.p:
Find an orthogonal basis \{u_1,u_2\} for W = \Span\{v_1,v_2\}, where
v_1 = \vec{1 1 0} \qquad v_2 = \vec{1 1 1}.

solution.p:
We run GramSchmidt: first take u_1 = v_1, then
u_2 = v_2 - \frac{v_2\cdot u_1}{u_1\cdot u_1}\,u_1 = \vec{1 1 1} - \frac{2}{2}\vec{1 1 0} = \vec{0 0 1}.
Then \{u_1,u_2\} is an orthogonal basis for W: indeed, it is clear that u_1\cdot u_2 = 0.

statement.p: Find an orthogonal basis \{u_1,u_2,u_3\} for W = \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_3\} = \R^3, where v_1 = \vec{1 1 0} \qquad v_2 = \vec{1 1 1} \qquad v_3 = \vec{3 1 1}.

Find an orthogonal basis \{u_1,u_2,u_3\} for W = \Span\{v_1,v_2,v_3\}, where
v_1 = \vec[r]{1 1 1 1} \qquad v_2 = \vec[r]{-1 4 4 -1} \qquad v_3 = \vec[r]{4 -2 -2 0}.

subsection.p: We saw in the proof of the GramSchmidt Process that for every i between 1 and m, the set \{u_1,u_2,\ldots,u_i\} is a an orthogonal basis for \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_i\}.

bluebox.p: You can use the GramSchmidt Process to produce an orthogonal basis from any spanning set: if some u_i = 0, just throw away u_i and v_i, and continue.

subsection.title: Two Methods to Compute the Projection
subsection.p:
We have now presented two methods for computing the orthogonal projection of a vector: this involves row reduction, and the requires an orthogonal basis. Here are some guidelines for which to use in a given situation.
If you already have an orthogonal basis, it is almost always easier to use the . This often happens in the sciences.
If you are going to have to compute the projections of many vectors onto the same subspace, it is worth your time to run GramSchmidt to produce an orthogonal basis, so that you can use the .
If you only have to project one or a few vectors onto a subspace, it is faster to use the . This is the method we will follow in .
